datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_quantitativeMassSpec_Dooren_Mitochondrial_Matrix_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Toxoplasma mitochondrial matrix proteome determined using two independent, biotin-labelling approaches: ascorbate peroxidase (APEX) approach and the BirA*/BioID approach.
datasetPresenter.description:
Toxoplasma mitochondrial matrix proteome determined using two independent, biotin-labelling approaches: ascorbate peroxidase (APEX) approach and the BirA*/BioID approach.

Sample Names:
RH-APEXvsHM = control APEX vs mitoAPEX
RH-BirAvsHBA = BirA vs mitoBirA

Quantitative proteomics pipeline.
Statistically-relevant protein expression changes were identified using a custom pipeline as previously described (Delconte et al., 2016). Probability values were corrected for multiple testing using Benjaminiâ€“Hochberg method. Cut-off lines with the function y= -log10(0.05)+c/(x-x0) (Keilhauer et al., 2015) were introduced to identify significantly enriched proteins. c was set to 0.2 while x0 was set to 1 representing proteins that are differentially expressed within 1 or 2 standard deviations.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_massSpec_Dogga_N-terminal_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Toxoplasma gondii RH N-terminal Peptides
datasetPresenter.description:
Toxoplasma gondii RH proteome from wild type (-ATc) and ASP3 knockdown (+ATc) cells were digested by trypsin, then labelled with the TMT10plex reagents, pooled, then subjected to TAILS and MS. The dataset includes two samples: TMT10TAILS labelled peptides and TMT10TAILS N-terminal peptides. The later being a subset of the former.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_massSpec_Extracellular_Vesicles_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Toxoplasm gondii RH Extracellular vesicles proteomics
datasetPresenter.description: Extracellular vesicles (EV) from Toxoplasm gondii RH cells grown in axenic culture, HFF-infected cells and non-infected HFF cells. EVs were isolated from conditioned media and protein extracts were separated by SDS-Page. Peptides from gel slices were analyzed by LC-MS/MS. MS data were searched against reference proteomes for H. sapens and T gondii downloaded from the UniProt consortium. Data from triplicate preparations were pooled to create the proteomes for the three ssamples: TgEV, ICEV, NICEV.

datasetPresenter.name: ccayCHN_HEN01_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Cyclospora cayetanensis strain CHN_HEN01.
datasetPresenter.description:
The genome of Cyclospora cayetanensis strain CHN_HEN01 was sequenced using 454 GS FLX Titanium and Illumina technologies.

Assembly method: CLC NGS Cell v. 4.1.0
Genome coverage: 200.0x
Sequencing technology: 454; Illumina GAIIx

DNA isolation, Sequencing and Assembly:
DNA was extracted from a C. cayetanensis specimen collected in July 2011 from a patient in Kaifeng, Henan, China. The identification of C. cayetanensis was done by acid-fast microscopy and confirmed by PCR and sequence analyses of the SSU rRNA gene. DNA was extracted from sucrose and cesium chloride gradient-purified oocysts. The genome of C. cayetanensis was sequenced using the Roche 454 GS-FLX Titanium with average read lengths of 400â€“450 bp. Supplemental 100 Ã— 100 bp paired-end sequencing was completed using the Illumina Genome Analyzer IIx. After sequencing, 454 sequence reads were assembled using Roche Newbler (gsAssembler 2.3). Illumina reads were trimmed. Trimmed reads were assembled de novo with the clc_assembler. Contigs for C. cayetanensis apicoplast and mitochondrion genes were identified by blasting the assemblies against the GenBank database.

Oocysts of Cyclospora cayetanensis isolate CHN-HEN01 under differential interference contrast microscopy (left) and epifluorescence microscopy using a 330â€“380 nm ultraviolet excitation filter (right). All pictures were taken under Ã—400.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_massSpec_Wastling_Hsapiens_infection_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Proteome During Infection in H. sapiens (ME49 VEG GT1 RH)
datasetPresenter.summary: T. gondii peptide sequences from a proteomic analysis of a mixed parasite/host sample collected during infection in human foreskin fibroblasts.
datasetPresenter.description:
Proteomic analysis of Toxoplasma gondii during infection of human foreskin fibroblast cells.

T. gondii tachyzoites were propagated on Vero cells before being used to infect human foreskin fibroblasts (HFFs). Confluent monolayers of HFFs were infected with approximately 10E^7 tachyzoites.

Protein preparations from infected cultures (human and parasite mixed) were trypsin digested, mixed with peptide internal standards and analysed by LC-MS/MS. Resulting spectra were searched (Mascot v2.3) against a combination of T. gondii protein sequence database (ToxoDB's "ToxoDB-8.0_TgondiiME49_AnnotatedProteins") and Human protein reference sequence database (UniProt, May 2013).

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_massSpec_Wastling_Oocysts_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: T. gondii Type II M4 oocyst proteome determined using quantitative methods
datasetPresenter.description:
The oocyst proteome from Toxoplasma gondii Type II M4 was determined using quantitative methods.

Oocysts were harvested from the feces of infected kittens, allowed to sporulate for 10 days, and purified by CsCl gradient. Protein preparations from sporulated oocysts were trypsin digested, mixed with a peptide internal standard and analyzed by LC-MS/MS. Resulting spectra were searched (Mascot v2.3) against a T. gondii ME49 protein sequence database (ToxoDB's "ToxoDB-8.0_TgondiiME49_AnnotatedProteins")

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_massSpec_deMonerriUbiquitin_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: T. gondii RH tachyzoite ubiquitinated proteome aligned to TgME49.
datasetPresenter.description:
Ubiquitination of the Toxoplasma gondii RH tachyzoite proteome was analyzed by LC-MS/MS and peptides were aligned to ME49.

The genome of Toxoplasma gondii encodes ubiquitination machinery, but the roles of this posttranslational modification (PTM) are unknown. To examine the prevalence and function of ubiquitination in T. gondii, we mapped the ubiquitin proteome of tachyzoites. Over 500 ubiquitin-modified proteins, with almost 1,000 sites, were identified on proteins with diverse localizations and functions.

For isolation of intracellular parasites, HFFs were infected and harvested at 36-Â–40 hr by scraping, sequential syringe lysis, and filtration through a 3 micrometer polycarbonate filter. Extracellular tachyzoites that had lysed host cells were harvested approximately 45 hr post-infection and filtered as above.

Digestion of ubiquitin-protein conjugates by trypsin results in a diglycine remnant attached to the ubiquitinated lysine residue. Anti-diglycyl lysine antibodies are used to purify ubiquitinated peptides. Purified diglycine peptides were analyzed by LC-MS/MS, and the resulting spectra were searched against a combined database of T. gondii and human proteins and a decoy database, using the Mascot algorithm.

datasetPresenter.name: sneuSN3_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Sarcocystis neurona strain SN3 genome sequence and annotation.
datasetPresenter.description:
Sarcocystis neurona, SN3 strain, was cultured on bovine cells and sequenced using 454 pyrosequencing and Sanger sequencing of fosmid ends. The raw reads were assembled using Newbler 2.5. The assembled genome has been screened to remove bovine contaminants. The genome was sequenced at the UK-Advanced Genetic Technologies Center, University of Kentucky. The genome was sequenced and assembled by the laboratories of Daniel K. Howe and Christopher L. Schardl, University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY,USA

The annotation was created using the evidence-based MAKER annotation pipeline. Evidence for the MAKER pipeline includes S. neurona transcriptome data and proteins from other apicomplexans. The Draft annotation work was performed by the research group of Jessica C. Kissinger, University of Georgia, Athens, GA, USA.

The fosmid library was constructed in the copy control vector pCC2FOS using the CopyControl HTP Fosmid library production kit (Epicenter biotechnologies). Paired-end sequencing of the fosmids was done using the Sanger method. The sequenced paired-ends were used in generating the S. neurona genome assembly.
datasetPresenter.releasePolicy: It is the intention of the authors to publish this work. They are providing this data as a service to the community to facilitate their research. Please contact the authors prior to embarking on any whole genome analyses until the sequence and primary analysis are published.
datasetPresenter.history: newly-annotated and apicoplast genome and annotation added

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_Vinayak_FosmidEnds_clonedInsertEnds_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Toxoplasma gondii RH sequence from fosmid ends mapped against T. gondii ME49
datasetPresenter.description:
The Toxoplasma gondii RH fosmid library was constructed by Sumiti Vinayak in the copy control vector pCC2FOS. Fosmid ends were sequenced commercially (Sanger method) using vector specific primers. Resulting sequences were aligned to the T. gondii ME49 genome using BLAST.

Funds for sequencing were provided by Boris Striepen (University of Georgia, Athens, GA, USA), Markus Meissner (University of Glasgow, Scotland) and Michael White (University of South Florida, Tampa, FL, USA).
datasetPresenter.caveat: Note that fosmid inserts typically are not larger than ~45,000 bp (mean size ~34,000 bp), very large inserts depicted in gbrowse may reflect mismatched end sequences.

datasetPresenter.name: _massSpec_Boothroyd_Elias_Moritz_Phosphoproteome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Tachyzoite phosphoproteome from purified parasite or infected host cell (RH)
datasetPresenter.shortDisplayName: TgRH Tachy Pure vs Infect PhosProt
datasetPresenter.summary: Proteome of phosphopeptide enriched or depleted samples from host cells infected with T. gondii RH tachyzoite or from the same parasites purified from infected host cells.
datasetPresenter.description:
Protein samples were prepared from infected host cells or from purified T. gondii RH strain tachyzoites. Phosphorylated and non-phosphorylated peptides were separated by SCX chromotography, enriched by IMAC chromotography, and analyzed by LC-MS/MS. To discover the peptide composition of samples, mass spec data was searched against TgME49 and TgGT1 peptide databases. Sample collection and mass-spectrometry were performed by Moritz Treeck and John Sanders of the Boothroyd and Elias labs at Stanford University, respectively.

Intracellular RH tachyzoite samples:
Tachyzoites (RH strain) were used to infect HFF (human foreskin fibroblasts) for 28h. Extracellular parasites were washed off and the parasite-infected host cells lysed and the entire sample used for phosphopeptide enrichment and mass-spectrometry.

Purified RH tachyzoite samples:
Purified tachyzoite samples (RH strain) were prepared by infection of HFFs with RH parasites for 28h. To remove host cell material and parasite proteins present within the host cell or parasitophorous vacuole, the infected cultures were syringe-lysed and the released parasites were then purified by gel chromatography as described in Dunn et. al., 2008 (Infection & Immunity).

Sample Preparation and Proteomics
All parasite samples were lysed in 8m urea lysis buffer, followed by trypsin digestion, strong-cation-exchange (SCX) chromatography and IMAC phosphopeptide enrichment (Villen and Gygi, 2008). Samples enriched for phosphopeptides and the flow through (containing predominantly non-phosphorylated peptides) were analyzed in duplicate via LC-MS/MS and the resulting spectra were searched against appropriate parasite protein sequence databases concatenated with reversed decoy versions of these sequences using the SEQUEST algorithm (Eng et al., 1994). Phosphorylation sites were localized using the AScore algorithm (Beausoleil et al., 2006) and the dataset was filtered using the target-decoy strategy (Elias and Gygi 2007, 2010) for peptide and phosphorylation site-FDRs <1% and a protein FDR <3%. This bulk FDR prediction estimates that fewer than 1% of the identifications are incorrect. Given that a phosphopeptide was correctly identified, its phosphorylation sites are necessarily present, but the siteâ€™s localization to a specific amino acid can be ambiguous. As a result, the Ascore algorithm was used to help localize phosphorylation sites to a specific residue. This algorithm calculates the relative likelihood that the indicated amino acid is phosphorylated versus the next-most likely residue on the peptide. An Ascore >19 indicates a >99% likelihood that the indicated phosphorylation site is correctly assigned; an Ascore >13-represents a 95% likelihood; and an Ascore >10 corresponds with a >90% likelihood. As a rule of thumb, a phosphorylation site with many spectral counts, indicating many observations, tend to be more abundant than those with fewer spectral counts. While it is true that most incorrect identifications have few spectral counts, it is not necessarily the case that phosphorylation sites with few spectral counts are incorrect. Further scores to evaluate each individual site and peptide can be found in the supplementary data Table S1 and S2 in Treeck et. al., 2011.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_massSpec_Spano_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Proteome of partially sporulated oocysts from T. gondii VEG mapped to ME49
datasetPresenter.description:
Proteomics data from partially sporulated Toxoplasma gondii type III strain VEG oocysts (60% sporulated, 40% non sporulated) researched against the TgME49 proteome.

Total or fractionated protein extracts from sucrose gradient-purified VEG oocysts were analysed by one-dimensional gel electrophoresis LC-MS/MS in three independent experiments, producing a dataset of 1304 non redundant proteins.

Raw spectra were analysed by Bioworks Browser 3.3.1 using the Sequest 3.1 search engine against an indexed database containing all predicted tryptic peptides from T. gondii proteins (ToxoDB release 5.1 and 7.1).

datasetPresenter.description:
Toxoplasma gondii FOU strain genome sequence data were produced by JCVI as part of the Toxoplasma white paper.


Data Usage Policy

NIAID is committed to rapid, pre-publication release of genomic data and recognizes that clinical data and other metadata associated with the genomic data are valuable research resources. For these reasons, NIAID endorses rapid release of all genome data sets. To comply with this policy, the whole genome sequences of T. gondii strains are being submitted to NCBI and included here in ToxoDB prior to complete annotation. Once annotation is complete and submitted to GenBank, the entries for these new genomes will be updated in ToxoDB. The users of any released data are expected to act responsibly to recognize the scientific contribution of the data producers by following normal standards of scientific etiquette and fair use of unpublished data. In particular, we ask that users not perform genome wide comparisons/analyses of the sequence/open reading frames/genes of the data sets deposited here without first contacting the organizing committee. We welcome your input in this process, but would also like to coordinate community efforts to with the goal of producing a collective report for publication. If you have an idea for analyses that would be useful, please contact one of us to coordinate your contribution to the community effort.


Brian Brunk, Hernan Lorenzi, David Roos & David Sibley, on behalf of the Toxoplasma genome consortium, representing the white paper committee, the JCVI genome sequencing center, and the ToxoDB team.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_microarrayExpression_Sullivan_GSE22100_GCN5-A_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Differential expression of TgGCN5-A null mutant under Alkaline growth conditions compared to wild type.
datasetPresenter.description:
Differential expression of TgGCN5-A null mutant under Alkaline growth conditions compared to wild type.

Disruption of the gene encoding for TgGCN5-A in type I RH strain did not produce a severe phenotype under normal culture conditions, but here we show that the TgGCN5-A null mutant is deficient in responding to alkaline pH, a common stress used to induce bradyzoite differentiation in vitro. We performed a genome- wide analysis of the Toxoplasma transcriptional response to alkaline pH stress, finding that parasites deleted for TgGCN5-A fail to up-regulate 74% of the stress response genes that are induced 2-fold or more in wild-type. Using chromatin immunoprecipitation, we verify an enrichment of TgGCN5-A at the upstream regions of genes activated by alkaline pH exposure. The TgGCN5-A knockout is also incapable of up-regulating key marker genes expressed during development of the latent cyst form, and is impaired in its ability to recover from alkaline stress. Complementation of the TgGCN5-A knockout restores the expression of these stress-induced genes and reverses the stress recovery defect. Click here for link to GEO

Authors: Arunasalam Naguleswaran, Eliana V. Elias, Jeanette McClintick, Howard J. Edenberg, William J. Sullivan Jr

templateInjector.prop: There are 4 samples divided based on two criteria 1. Strain Type a. Wild Type: unmodified ME49 strain b. GCN5-A Knockout: ME49 with GCN5-A gene deletion 2. Growth Conditions a. unstressed: samples were grown in standard culture medium b. stressed: samples were grown in alkaline culture medium
RMA Normalized Values (log base 2 generated with RMAExpress v1.0.3) or expression percentile value.The RMA values in log2 scale.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_microarrayExpression_Kim_PMRT1_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: PMRT1 KO, WT and KOCM expression profiles
datasetPresenter.summary: Expression profiles of arginine methyltransferase 1 (PMRT1) knockout, complement and wild type T. gondii RH-hxgprt parasites determined by Affymetrix microarray (Toxo Gene chip)
datasetPresenter.description:
Whole-genome microarray expression profiling to compare the wild-type, Δprmt1, and complemented Δprmt1::PRMT1mRFP strains.

The arginine methyltransferase family (PRMT) has been implicated in a variety of cellular processes, including signal transduction, epigenetic regulation, and DNA repair pathways. PRMT1 is thought to be responsible for the majority of PRMT activity in Toxoplasma gondii, but its exact function is unknown. In this study T. gondii mutants lacking PRMT1 (Δprmt1, KO) by deletion of the PRMT1 gene were generated as well as the complement (Δprmt1::PRMT1mRFP, CM). Whole genome expression profiles of WT, KO and CM strains were generated via Affymetrix microarray and can be interrogated to determine the role of PMRT1.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_Reid_tachy_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Tachyzoite Transcriptome 3 and 4 days post-infection (VEG NcLIV)
datasetPresenter.summary: Transcriptomic analysis of T. gondii VEG and N. caninum Liverpool tachyzoites at 3 and 4 days post-infection using paired-end Illumina RNA sequencing.
datasetPresenter.description:
Transcriptomic analysis of T. gondii VEG and N. caninum Liverpool tachyzoites at 3 and 4 days post-infection using paired-end Illumina RNA sequencing.

The transcriptomes of the invasive stage (tachyzoite) of N. caninum Liverpool and T. gondii VEG were determined using mRNA sequencing (mRNAseq) on an Illumina GAIIx machine. Parasites were grown asynchronously and harvested at 3 and 4 days post-infection. Poly A+ mRNA was purified from total RNA used to dscDNA. Fragments were selected for 200â€“250 bp inserts amplified by PCR to enrich for properly ligated template strands. Libraries were sequenced using the Illumina Genome Analyzer IIX in paired-end mode for 2Ã—76 cycles.

templateInjector.prop: T. gondii ME49 Day 3 and Day 4 Tachyzoite Form

Transcript levels of fragments per kilobase of exon model per million mapped reads (FPKM). Note that Non-Unique reads are ignored in the expression graphs. This means that the expression of duplicated genes (or gene families) might be underrepresented. Please consult the non-unique aligned read tracks in the genome browser to determine if your gene of interest contains non-uniquely aligned reads. The percentile graph shows the ranking of expression for this gene compared to all others in this experiment.

datasetPresenter.summary: Sequence and annotation for the Toxoplasma gondii VEG genome.
datasetPresenter.description:
Genome sequence and annotation for Toxoplasma gondii VEG.
The Toxoplasma gondii VEG nuclear genome comprises 12 chromosomes and is estimated to be around 62Mb in size. The genome was sequences to 77.38X coverage using a combination of Illumnia and Sanger technology. The genome assembly (Newbler v. 2.6) consists of 14 chromosomal sequences and 12 supercontigs.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_microarrayExpression_Roos-Tz_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Expression profiling of two strains from each of the 3 archetypal T. gondii lineages. This data was graciously provided to ToxoDB pre-publication by Paul Davis and David Roos.
datasetPresenter.description:
Expression profiling of two strains from each of the 3 archetypal T. gondii lineages was generated as per the following experiment:
At least three T25 flasks containing confluent monolayers of human foreskin fibroblasts grown in D10 media were infected with approximately 1x107 T. gondii tachyzoite parasites per strain. After 6hrs, the media was replaced with fresh D10. Approximately 40hr post-infection (and prior to observable host cell lysis), media was removed and flasks were washed once with 1x cold PBS. Cell monolayers were scraped in 5ml 1x cold PBS, and centrifuged for 12min, 750g at 4C. Supernatant was removed, and RNA was isolated from the cell pellets using Qiagen RNEasy kit according to manufacturer's instructions.
Strains utilized:
Type I:   RH and GT1
Type II:  Pru and ME49
Type III: CTG and VEG
This data was graciously provided to ToxoDB pre-publication by Paul Davis and David Roos.

templateInjector.prop: RMA Normalized Values (log base 2 generated with RMAExpress v1.0.3)

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_massSpec_Boothroyd_Bowyer_oocyst_sporozoite_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Proteomes of oocyst walls, sporocysts/sporozoites cytosol and membrane fractions from Toxoplasma gondii Type II M4 strain oocysts.
datasetPresenter.description:
Mature "day 10" Toxoplasma gondii Type II M4 strain oocysts were fractionated into walls (bleach treated, and untreated) and sporocysts/sporozoites. Protein preparations were analyzed by 1DE, LC-MS/MS.

Heather M. Fritz*, Paul W. Bowyer*, Matthew Bogyo, Patricia A. Conrad, John C. Boothroyd *these authors contributed equally to this work

Mature "day 10" Toxoplasma gondii oocysts of the Type II M4 strain were used for proteomic characterization of the wall and sporocyst/sporozoite fractions of the oocyst by mass spectrometry. Two experiments using 100 million oocysts each were performed. For each experiment oocysts were fractionated into wall and sporocyst/sporozoite components. In the second experiment, the 100 million oocysts were first divided into bleach-treated and not-treated fractions. Bleach treatment was used to remove the outer layer of the bilayered oocyst wall before fractionation. Therefore, comparison of the bleach-treated to not-treated walls allowed us to interrogate the inner versus outer wall location of identified proteins in the wall fraction. Data from the bleach-treated and not-treated sporocyst fractions in experiment two were pooled, as bleach treatment of the intact oocysts should not affect the sporocysts within.

Peptide identifications for the following oocyst fractions are provided:
1. Oocyst walls
2. Sporocysts/Sporozoites Cytosol
3. Sporocysts/Sporozoites Membrane


Sample preparation:

Oocyst harvest, bleach treatment and fractionation into walls and sporocysts/sporozoites
Unsporulated oocysts were harvested from the feces of infected kittens and sporulated for 10 days. Sporulated oocysts were then purified using a CsCl gradient separation. Half of the oocysts in the second experiment were treated with bleach to remove the outer layer of the oocyst wall. For each sample, oocysts were separated into walls and sporocysts using an iodixanol (Optiprep, SIGMA) gradient separation.

Protein Preparation and Mass Spectrometry (MS)
Oocyst fractions were separated by 1-D SDS-PAGE on a 7 cm long gel. The entire length of each sample lane was cut into 14, 0.5 cm, slices. Gel slices were subjected to in-gel digestion with trypsin before analysis on an LTQ ion trap mass spectrometer (ThermoFisher).

LC-MS/MS
Peptides were separated on a Basic Picofrit C18 capillary column coupled to an Eksigent nanoLC-2Dï£ª pump before analysis on an LTQ ion trap. Peptides were eluted with an acetonitrile gradient from 0 to 60% in a 0.1% solution of formic acid over 2hr. Dynamic exclusion was enabled for 180 sec.

Data Analysis
Searches were performed against a custom concatenated target-decoy database containing the annotated proteins based on the T. gondii ME49 release 5 sequences. Peptides in the +1, +2 and +3 charge-states were required to have minimum XCorr values of 1.8, 2.5 and 3.5, respectively. The minimum requirement for deltaCN was 0.08. Both tryptic and semi-tryptic peptides are shown.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_massSpec_Wastling_ME49_tachyzoites_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Proteome of T gondii RH tachyzoites (harvested 3-4 days post-infection)
datasetPresenter.description:
Total protein from T gondii RH tachyzoites (harvested 3-4 days post-infection) was analyzed by 1DE, LC-MS/MS and MudPIT analysis. Purified tachyzoites were either solubilized directly in SDS sample buffer or prepared as Tris-soluble and Tris insoluble fractions prior to 1DE, LC-MS/MS. MudPit analysis was performed on Tris-soluble and Tris-insoluble fractions. Proteomics data includes the following samples:

1-D SDS PAGE Total Fraction
1-D SDS PAGE Soluble Fraction
1-D SDS PAGE Insoluble Fraction
MudPIT Soluble Fraction
MudPIT Insoluble Fraction

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_chipChipExper_Einstein_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Chromatin Immunoprecipitation (RH PLK CTG) - Active Transcriptome
datasetPresenter.summary: Chromatin Immunoprecipitation chip data identifying regions of active transcription. Peak calls were made by the data provider.
datasetPresenter.description:
Type I (RH) / Type II (PLK) / Type III (CTG) tachyzoites; green=H3K4Me3; orange=H3K9ac; (Einstein) Evidence of expression in Type I (RH) tachyzoites based on ChIP-chip peaks.

Two different antibodies were used identifying different chromatin marks which indicate active transcription. Coincident Histone 3 Lysine 4 trimethylation (H3K4me3) and Histone 3 Lysine 9 acetylation (H3K9ac) peaks are highly correlated with active promoters, with H3K4me3 marks oriented closer to the 5' end of the gene. Experiments were performed in duplicate -- H3K4Me3 replicas are in shades of green and H3K9ac replicas are in shades of orange.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_chipChipExper_Einstein_ME1_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Chromatin Immunoprecipitation chip data identifying regions of active transcription in T. gondii RH tachyzoites using H3K4me1. Peak calls were made by the data provider.
datasetPresenter.description: Chromatin Immunoprecipitation Microarray - Einstein ME1 Chromatin Immunoprecipitation chip data identifying active transcriptional units. RH chromatin was immunoprecipitated from intracellular tachyzoites using antibodies specific for Histone 3 monomethyl-Lysine 4 (H3K4me1) and hybridized to a custom Nimblegen T. gondii genome microarray (Version 4.3; ME49 genome). The position of H3K4me1 correlates with active transcriptional units. Chromatin was harvested from intracellular parasites grown in HFF. This data was generated by Mathieu Gissot, J. Eduardo Fajardo, Louis M. Weiss, Andras Fiser, Kami Kim Albert Einstein College of Medicine, This data was graciously provided to ToxoDB pre-publication.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonTgCATBr9_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence of Toxoplasma gondii TgCATBr9 strain
datasetPresenter.description:
Toxoplasma gondii TgCATBr9 strain genome sequence data were produced by JCVI as part of the Toxoplasma white paper.


Data Usage Policy

NIAID is committed to rapid, pre-publication release of genomic data and recognizes that clinical data and other metadata associated with the genomic data are valuable research resources. For these reasons, NIAID endorses rapid release of all genome data sets. To comply with this policy, the whole genome sequences of T. gondii strains are being submitted to NCBI and included here in ToxoDB prior to complete annotation. Once annotation is complete and submitted to GenBank, the entries for these new genomes will be updated in ToxoDB. The users of any released data are expected to act responsibly to recognize the scientific contribution of the data producers by following normal standards of scientific etiquette and fair use of unpublished data. In particular, we ask that users not perform genome wide comparisons/analyses of the sequence/open reading frames/genes of the data sets deposited here without first contacting the organizing committee. We welcome your input in this process, but would also like to coordinate community efforts to with the goal of producing a collective report for publication. If you have an idea for analyses that would be useful, please contact one of us to coordinate your contribution to the community effort.


Brian Brunk, Hernan Lorenzi, David Roos & David Sibley, on behalf of the Toxoplasma genome consortium, representing the white paper committee, the JCVI genome sequencing center, and the ToxoDB team.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_Gregory_VEG_mRNA_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: T. gondii VEG tachyzoite mRNA Illumina sequences aligned to the ME49 Genome
datasetPresenter.description:
Transcript expression was assayed in T. gondii tachyzoites. The experiment was conducted as follows:

T. gondii tachyzoites were propagated on Vero cells before being used to infect Human Foreskin Fibroblasts (HFFs). T25 flasks containing confluent monolayers of HFFs were infected with approximately 10E^7 tachyzoites.

T. gondii tachyzoite total RNA was extracted at 2, 4, 8, 16, 36, and 44 hours post-infection.

Media was removed, cell monolayers were scraped in 700ul of Qiazol, and RNA was isolated from the cell lysates using the Qiagen miRNEasy mini kit according to manufacturer's instructions. 6 flasks (biological replicates) were collected per timepoint, and were checked for RNA quality using a BioAnalyzer (Agilent). Biological replicates were pooled and total and polyA+ selected RNA was used to construct strand specific small non-coding or mRNA libraries respectively, that were sequenced on Illumina Hi-Seq 2000 and Genome Analyzer machines.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_microarrayExpression_Matrajt_GSE23174_Bz_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Mutants and wild-type expression profiles during bradyzoite differentiation
datasetPresenter.summary: Microarray analysis of seven novel T. gondii insertional mutants that do not undergo normal differentiation to bradyzoites.
datasetPresenter.description:
Microarray analysis of seven novel T. gondii insertional mutants that do not undergo normal differentiation to bradyzoites. Whole genome expression profiling was carried out on the Affymetrix ToxoGeneChip (GeneChip Tgondiia520372) in order to analyze the ~8,000 predicted genes in the T. gondii genome of mutants and wild-type, allowing for full-scale expression profiling during bradyzoite differentiation in vitro.

Three experiments are available: Differentiation Mutant Expression - 11 hours post-egress:
Extracellular Tachyzoite
Wild Type: Post-Egress
13P Mutant: Post-Egress
B7 Mutant: Post-Egress

Differentiation time series:
Extracellular Tachyzoite (0 hrs)
Bradyzoite (24 hrs)
Bradyzoite (36 hrs)
Bradyzoite (48 hrs)
Bradyzoite (72 hrs)

Differentiation Mutant Transcript Expression: Control: Tachyzoite Intracellular Tachyzoite Control: Bradyzoite 12K Mutant: Tachyzoite 12K Mutant: Bradyzoite 13P Mutant: Tachyzoite 13P Mutant: Bradyzoite B7 Mutant: Tachyzoite B7 Mutant: Bradyzoite 11P Mutant: Tachyzoite 11P Mutant: Bradyzoite 11K Mutant: Tachyzoite 11K Mutant: Bradyzoite 7K Mutant: Tachyzoite 7K Mutant: Bradyzoite P11 Mutant: Tachyzoite P11 Mutant: Bradyzoite

templateInjector.prop: bz_mutant_rma & bz_egress_rma - Organism Type: Lifecycle Stage\\nbz_time_series_rma - Hours from differentiation
RMA Normalized Values (log base 2 generated with RMAExpress v1.0.3) or expression percentile value.The RMA values in log2 scale.

datasetPresenter.name: efalBayerHaberkorn1970_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Eimeria falciformis Bayer Haberkorn 1970 sequence and annotation
datasetPresenter.description: Draft genome sequence of the mouse parasite Eimeria falciformis Bayer Haberkorn 1970 was determined using a next generation sequencing approach comprising one standard paired-end and one mate pair library with ~ 2 Kilobase (Kb) insert size sequenced with Illumina technology. A total nominal sequencing coverage of more than 500X allowed the construction of a largely contiguous whole genome sequence. We assembled 753 high quality contigs covering a sequence space of 43.7 Mb with a median weighted contig size (N50) of ~250 kb and thus conclude a genome size of roughly 44 Mb.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_microarrayExpression_White_GSE16037_Tz-Bz_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Bradyzoite Differentiation Expression Profiles (ME49, GT1, CTGara)
datasetPresenter.summary: Expression profiles of T. gondii ME49, GT1 and CTGara tachyzoites and corresponding bradyzoites induced by compound 1 or pH 8.2 incubation.
datasetPresenter.description:
Lineage and developmental gene expression: type I GT1, type II Me49, and type III CTGara strains under normal (tachyzoite) and induced (Compound 1 and pH 8.2) conditions.

Whole-cell mRNA levels in both tachyzoite and bradyzoite populations from three primary strain isolates (differentiated in vitro) were analyzed by microarray. Type I-GT1, Type II-Me49B7 and Type III-CTG strains were maintained at < 20 cell culture passages from the oocyst stage and are capable of completing both intermediate and definitive host life cycles. These experiments used Toxoplasma gondii Affymetrix microarray that includes probe sets for ~8000 genes, and induction of bradyzoite genes was assessed using a strong inducer of bradyzoite differentiation, Compound 1. The alkaline condition data set was graciously provided directly by Michael Behnke and Michael White.

Samples:
GT1 tachyzoite
GT1 Compound 1
GT1 pH 8.2
ME49 tachyzoite
ME49 Compound 1
ME49 pH 8.2
CTGara tachyzoite
CTGara Compound 1
CTGara pH 8.2

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_massSpec_Tonkin_Phosphoproteome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: T. gondii RH strain tachyzoites were stimulated with the calcium-mobilizing agent and proteomes determined for phospopeptide enriched and depleted fractions.
datasetPresenter.description: Protein samples were prepared from T. gondii RH strain tachyzoites that were stimulated with the calcium-mobilizing agent, ionomycin. Phosphopeptide-enriched and phosphopeptide-depleted fractions were separated by SCX chromotography, enriched by IMAC chromotography, and analyzed by MudPIT. Peptide discovery was performed on mass spec data using the SEQUEST or MASCOT algorithms as indicated. 305 non-redundant Toxoplasma phosphopeptides were identified.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_massSpec_Einstein_preprocessed_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Enriched cytoskeletal and membrane fractions of T. gondii (RH) were analyzed using three different proteomics techniques: 1DE, LC-MS/MS; 2DE, LC-MS/MS; or LC-MS/MS.
datasetPresenter.description: Enriched cytoskeletal and membrane fractions of T. gondii RH were separated by 1D-SDS-PAGE or 2D gel electrophoresis. The bands/spots were digested with trypsin. The resulting peptides analyzed by nanoLC-MS/MS on a ThermoFinnigan linear ion trap (LTQ) mass spectrometer. MASCOT was used to search the merged DTA mass spectrometry data file against the appropriate database to obtained unique peptide hits. In order to extend the dynamic range of the membrane fractions, high pH sodium carbonate was used to remove the peripheral membrane proteins. For a few experiments, the remaining cytosolic fractions were also analyzed. A total of 2604 proteins were identified. The 2604 predicted proteins cluster into 1534 groups of overlapping gene predictions that were identified by 14455 mass spectrometry peptide hits that gave an average 13.2% sequence coverage. Peptides from LC-MS/MS analysis by the Albert Einstein Biodefense Proteomics Research Center

datasetPresenter.name: etenHoughton_massSpec_Tomley_sporozoite_rhoptry_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: The rhoptry proteome of Eimeria tenella sporozoites
datasetPresenter.description:
The rhoptry proteome of Eimeria tenella sporozoites

Highly enriched preparations of rhoptry organelles from Eimeria tenella sporozoites were prepared via centrifugation through a sucrose gradient and used for proteomic analysis. Precipitated proteins were analyzed by 2DE, LC-MS/MS. Peptides were analysed by a Waters Q-TOF Premier mass spectrometer in data-directed acquisition mode, where a MS survey scan was used to automatically select multicharged peptides for further MS/MS fragmentation. Resulting peak lists were combined and searched using MASCOT against E. tenella predicted gene models.

datasetPresenter.description:
Serial Analysis of Gene Expression (SAGE) tags for T. gondii

RH strain tachyzoites were maintained by serial passage in human foreskin fibroblasts. SAGE libraries were constructed from cDNA that was synthesized from 1 Î¼g of total RNA using the Smartâ„¢ cDNA synthesis reagents. Delineation of sequence, extraction of SAGE tag information, frequency analyses and tag sequence annotation were all completed using Perl 5.6.1 running in a UNIX RedHat 7.2 environment with Perl scripts.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_microarrayExpression_BoothroydAnderson_Tz-Bz_RSRC
datasetPresenter.shortAttribution: Buchholz, Fritz and Boothroyd et al.
datasetPresenter.summary: Microarray gene expression profiles during differention from tachyzoites to bradyzoites
datasetPresenter.description:
Microarray gene expression profiles during differention from tachyzoites to bradyzoites.

T. gondii Type II Prugniaud parasites lacking HXGPRT were inoculated at an MOI of 2 and differentiated in RPMI 1640 lacking sodium bicarbonate, low FCS, and high pH (8.1). RNA was collected from either tachyzoite (2 days post inoculation before monolayer lysis) or bradyzoite cultures (2-days, 3-days and 4-days of induction). Samples were analyzed by microarray on [Tgondiia520372] Affymetrix Toxoplasma gondii Custom GeneChip.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonRUB_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Sequence and Annotation of the Toxoplasma gondii RUB genome
datasetPresenter.description:
Toxoplasma gondii RUB strain genome sequence and annotation data were produced by JCVI as part of the Toxoplasma white paper.

The genome was sequenced using 454 GS FLX Titanium and Illumina technology to a 30 fold coverage. It was assembled using Newbler v. 2.5.3. EuPathDB downloaded the data from Genbank.

Data Usage Policy

NIAID is committed to rapid, pre-publication release of genomic data and recognizes that clinical data and other metadata associated with the genomic data are valuable research resources. For these reasons, NIAID endorses rapid release of all genome data sets. To comply with this policy, the whole genome sequences of T. gondii strains are being submitted to NCBI and included here in ToxoDB prior to complete annotation. Once annotation is complete and submitted to GenBank, the entries for these new genomes will be updated in ToxoDB. The users of any released data are expected to act responsibly to recognize the scientific contribution of the data producers by following normal standards of scientific etiquette and fair use of unpublished data. In particular, we ask that users not perform genome wide comparisons/analyses of the sequence/open reading frames/genes of the data sets deposited here without first contacting the organizing committee. We welcome your input in this process, but would also like to coordinate community efforts to with the goal of producing a collective report for publication. If you have an idea for analyses that would be useful, please contact one of us to coordinate your contribution to the community effort.


Brian Brunk, Hernan Lorenzi, David Roos & David Sibley, on behalf of the Toxoplasma genome consortium, representing the white paper committee, the JCVI genome sequencing center, and the ToxoDB team.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_massSpec_Sullivan_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: MS/MS analysis of peptides affinity purified from parasite lysate using an anti-acetyl-lysine antibody.
datasetPresenter.description: This dataset represents the lysine acetylome for Toxoplasma gondii RH intracellular and extracellular tachyzoites. Lysine-acetylated proteins were affinity purified from tachyzoites harvested from human foreskin fibroblasts (intracellular) and from tachyzoites harvested 1-2 hours post-egress (extracellular). Peptide samples were analyzed by LC-MS/MS and the resulting MS spectra were evaluated with SEQUEST 3G and Sorcerer 2.
datasetPresenter.usage: EuPathDB maps proteomics peptides to the genome and provides a search that returns genes based on these mappings. Peptide mappings are tabulated on gene record pages and peptides can be displayed in context with the genome using GBrowse.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_chipChipExper_Hakimi.Ali_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Histone acetylation sites in control or FR235222 treated Toxoplasma gondii RH determined by ChIP-chip analysis assay
datasetPresenter.description:
Using chromatin immunoprecipitation and microarray hybridization (Nimblegen arrays), we analyzed the patterns of DNA-bound Histone H4(K5-K8-K12-K16) acetylation after 4 hours treatment of Toxoplasma gondii RH strain with DMSO (control) or 40 nM of FR235222 (named previously drug A) which is a Toxoplasma-specific HDAC inhibitor. ChIP-on-chip isolated DNA samples (input and immunopurified DNA) were arrayed on custom synthetic oligo arrays (387,000 features per array, 46-50 mer oligos, 2 arrays for the whole genome; Nimblegen). Peak calls were made by the data provider.

Gene Expression Omnibus identifiers for the data sets = GSM380521, GSM380522

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_microarrayExpression_Boothroyd_LifeCycle_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Oocyst, tachyzoite, and bradyzoite developmental expression profiles (M4)
datasetPresenter.summary: Transcriptome analysis of oocyst, tachyzoite and bradyzoite development in the T. gondii type II strain M4.
datasetPresenter.description:
Transcriptome analysis of oocyst,tachyzoite and bradyzoite development in the type II strain M4.

There were three primary objectives to the overall experiment.

     I. Describe the transcriptome of the oocyst through its development beginning with the freshly excreted, unsporulated oocyst at "Day 0" to a fully sporulated and mature oocyst at "Day 10" and including a mid-sporulation time-point at "Day 4".
     II. Compare the transcriptomes of in vitro (4 and 8 days post infection (dpi)) vs. in vivo (21 dpi) derived bradyzoites.
     III. Compare expression data from three life stages (oocyst, bradyzoite and tachyzoite) from the same parasite isolate, M4. This isolate has been characterized as a Type II strain.

The RNA was derived from parasites donated by the Moredun Research Intstitute, Edinburgh, Scotland, UK and belong to the same original isolate (T. gondii M4: J. Gutierrez et al. Veterinary Parasitology 172 (2010) 8-15.)

More specifically, RNA samples were obtained from:

     1. Oocysts harvested from kitten feces and purified for RNA extraction at Day 0, (not sporulated), Day 4 post-induction of sporulation (mid-sporulation) and Day 10 post-induction of sporulation. Oocysts were collected and combined from two kittens that were infected with the same starting material (mouse brains containing bradyzoite cysts). Duplicate samples were obtained from feces collected and purified on separate days.
     2. Bradyzoite cysts harvested from the brains of mice that were infected with oocysts (obtained from the oocysts harvested from kittens as described for the oocyst RNA). Mice were treated with 0.44 ug/ml sulfadiazine in their water days 11-21 pi to enable a chronic infection state. Mice were sacrificed on day 21 for cyst purification.
     3. In vitro 4 and 8 dpi bradyzoite and 2 dpi tachyzoite samples are from separately infected cultures of human foreskin fibroblasts (HFF) (replicate flasks for each condition and time-point were infected on the same day). Samples were harvested independently and kept separate for all the subsequent processing and labeling steps. Bradyzoite differentiation was induced by growth under low serum (1%) high pH (8.0) conditions without supplemented CO2 as described (Fux, B. et. al. Infect Immun 75:2580-90, 2007).

Authors: Heather Fritz*, Kerry R. Buchholz*, Patricia Conrad, and John C. Boothoryd. (* these authors contributed equally.)

templateInjector.prop:
1. Time post infection or sporulation (i.e. 4d vs 8d Bradyzoites and 4d vs 10d sporulated oocyst).
2. Developmental form (Oocyst, Tachyzoite, Bradyzoite).
3. Bradyzoite samples - obtained in vitro vs. in vivo
The RMA values in log2 scale.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_SNP_Lindstrom_454_gff_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Aligned genomic sequence reads - TgCkUg2 Strain
datasetPresenter.summary: Whole genome resequencing data from T. gondii strain TgCkUg2 were used to call SNPs and determine CNV at the gene and chromosome level.
datasetPresenter.description:
Whole genome resequencing data from Toxoplasma gondii strain TgCkUg2 were analyzed for single nucleotide polymorphisms and copy number variation using T. gondii ME49 as a reference.

SNP analysis
Reads are aligned to the reference genome using Bowtie 2 and realigned around indels using GATK. SNPs, indels and concensus sequence are generated with VARSCAN and stored in the database.

CNV analysis
The median read depth is set to the organism's ploidy and each chromosome's median read depth is normalized to this value. Contigs that are not assigned to chromosomes are excluded from this analysis. Gene copy number is similarly calculated using a normalized read depth for each gene. To compare the number of genes in the resequenced genome to the reference genome, genes are grouped into clusters that are inferred to have originated by tandem duplication.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_HTS_SNP_Ramakrishnan_CZ_cloneH3_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Toxoplasma gondii strain CZ clone H3 aligned genome sequence
datasetPresenter.summary: Genomic DNA sequencing from Toxoplasma gondii strain CZ clone H3. Data were used to call SNPs and determine CNV.
datasetPresenter.description: Genomic DNA from Toxoplasma gondii strain CZ clone H3 was extracted from tachyzoites using the QIAamp DNA Mini Kit (QIAGEN). DNA was sheared with the Covaris Adaptive Focused Acoustics and size selected with AMpure beads (Beckman Coulter), end-repaired and polyadenylated. Libraries were generated using the TruSeq HT DNA NanoSample Prep Kit v2 (Illumina Inc.), and cluster generation was performed using the Hiseq 4000 PE Cluster Kit (Illumina Inc.). RNA-seq datasets from each time point post inoculation with bradyzoites in kittens were subjected to cluster analysis and assigned to five enteroepithelial developmental stages (EES) according to their profile.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_sageTag_White3primeSageTags_frequencies_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: 3' SAGE tag frequencies for T. gondii
datasetPresenter.description:
T. gondii 3' SAGE tag frequencies.
SAGE libraries were constructed and sequenced for:
sp - oocyst populations (containing mature sporozoites prior to release from the oocyst,
d4 - parasites emerging from the sporozoite-infected cell at Day-4 post-inoculation,
d6 - parasites rapidly growing in the second host cell (Day-6 post-sporozoite infection),
d7 - parasites immediately following the growth shift at Day-7 post-inoculation,
d15 - from slowly growing mixed tachyzoite-bradyzoite populations at Day-15 post-sporozoite inoculation,
ph - VEG parasites that were alkaline-differentiated into bradyzoites for 72 hours,
rh - TypeI-RH
b7 - TypeII-ME49B7
msj - TypeIII-VEGmsj

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_Knoll_Laura_Pittman_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Transcriptome during acute or chronic infection in mouse brain
datasetPresenter.summary: In vivo transcriptome analysis of Toxoplasma gondii during acute and chronic infection. RNA from the forebrain of infected and control mice was analyzed by paired-end Illumina sequencing.
datasetPresenter.description:
The transcriptome of Toxoplasma gondii during acute and chronic phase infections of CBA/J mice was determined using RNA sequencing. RNA was extracted from the forbrains of CBA/J mice in three experimental groups: acute infection (10 days post-infection), chronic infection (28 days post-infection) and uninfected (sacrificed at 28 days with the chronically infected mice). Three biological replicates at each time point were collected. The mixed parasite-mouse RNA was analyzed by paired-end sequencing (Illumina HiSeq2000).

This data was graciously provided to ToxoDB pre-publication by Matt Aliota, Kelly Pittman, and Laura Knoll

templateInjector.prop: Acute (10 days post infection) and chronic infection (28 days post infection)

datasetPresenter.summary: Comparative transcriptome analysis of 29 different strains of Toxoplasma gondii and the murine macrophages infected with them (HostDB).
datasetPresenter.description: The transcriptomes of 29 Toxoplasma gondii strains and of primary murine macrophages infected with them (HostDB) were determined by Illumina RNA sequencing. Primary bone marrow-derived macrophages from C57BL/6 mice were infected with 29 different T. gondii strains. Polyadenylated RNA was isolated 20-22 hours post-infection and sequenced using the Illumina Hi-Seq 2000.

datasetPresenter.displayName: T gondii Transcriptome during infection in 4 mouse cell types
datasetPresenter.summary: mRNA Illumina sequences from 4 different mouse cell types infected with T. gondii and aligned to the ME49 Genome.
datasetPresenter.description: Impact of the host cell type on the transcriptome of T. gondii during infection using high-throughput RNA sequencing. Murine cortical neurons and astrocytes, skeletal muscle cells (SkMCs) and fibroblasts were infected with Toxoplasma gondii strain NTE 3 and total RNA was isolated from mixed parasite host cultures 24 hours post infection. Single end 36 bp reads (SkMCs, astrocytes, fibroblasts) or single end 50 bp reads (neurons) of the library fragments were recorded.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_Hassan_intra_extra_ribo_profiling_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Comparative ribosome profiling of intracellular and extracellular parasites
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome-wide ribosome and mRNA sequence of intracellualr and extracellular T. gondii.
datasetPresenter.description: Type I Toxoplasma gondii was grown on human foreskin fibroblasts and intracellular or extracellular parasites collected after 24 hrs . Prior to harvesting, the parasite cultures were treated for about 10min with cyclohexamide (100ug/ml). After collection, the parasite samples were divided into two: one sample was used for ribosome profling, as previously described (Ingolia et al, 2009) and the other sample was used to extract total RNA for high throughput RNA-sequencing. Libraries were prepared according to Illumina's instructions. Libraries were sequenced on the Genome Analyzer following the manufacturer's protocols. See figure below for the experimental layout.

datasetPresenter.name: etenHoughton_Reid_RNASeq_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: RNA sequencing of the Eimeria tenella Houghton life cycle stages: unsporulated oocyst, sporulated oocyst, sporozoite, and 2nd generation merozoite.
datasetPresenter.description:
RNA sequencing of the Eimeria tenella Houghton life cycle stages: unsporulated oocyst (two biological replicates), sporulated oocyst(single replicate), sporozoite(single replicate), and 2nd generation merozoite (single replicate).

E. tenella Houghton strain parasites at specific life stages were harvested and purified. Total RNA was extracted from oocysts using a Qiagen RNeasy kit (Qiagen) and from sporozoites and second-generation merozoites using the Qiagen RNeasy Animal Cells purification protocol as described by the manufacturer. Poly A+ mRNA was purified from total RNA, converted to cDNA and libraries were sequenced using the Illumina Genome Analyzer IIX in paired-end mode for 2Ã—76 cycles.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_quantitativeMassSpec_Wastling_tgon_strains_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Proteome During an Infection in H. sapiens (Quant)(GT1 ME49 RH VEG)
datasetPresenter.summary: T. gondii peptide sequences from 6 proteomic analyses of mixed parasite/host cell samples that were collected during time course infections in human foreskin fibroblasts. (6 time course experiments using 4 different strains of T. gondii)
datasetPresenter.description:
Proteomic analysis of 4 Toxoplasma gondii strains during time course infections of human foreskin fibroblast cells (mixed parasite host cell samples)

T. gondii tachyzoites were propagated on Vero cells before being used to infect human foreskin fibroblasts (HFFs). Confluent monolayers of HFFs were infected with approximately 107 tachyzoites. Six individual time course experiments were performed:

Protein preparations from infected cultures (human and parasite mixed) were trypsin digested, mixed with peptide internal standards and analysed by LC-MS/MS. Resulting spectra were searched (PEAKS Studio 7.0) against a combination of T. gondii ME49 protein sequence database (ToxoDB's "ToxoDB-8.0_TgondiiME49_AnnotatedProteins") and Human protein reference sequence database (UniProt, May 2013). Quantitative analysis was carried out on Progenesis LC-MS v4.1 (Nonlinear Dynamics, UK).

This dataset has an equivalent analysis on the host proteome (See HostDB for details).

datasetPresenter.description:
RNA from the following Eimeria tenella Houghton life-cycle stages was paired-end sequenced using the Illumina HiSeq platform:

  • Gametocytes: mixture of both macrogametocytes (female) and microgametocytes (male).
  • Sporozoites: excysted from sporulated oocysts
  • Merozoites: 112 h post-infection (third-generation)


Total RNA was extracted from triplicate biological replicates representing each developmental stage, and paired-end sequencing was carried out on all RNA samples using the Illumina HiSeq platform.

datasetPresenter.name: tgonME49_Ramakrishnan_enteroepithelial_stages_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Feline enterocyte, tachyzoite, bradyzoite stage transcriptome
datasetPresenter.summary: Tanscriptomes of Toxoplasma gondii strain CZ clone H3 in feline enteroepithelial stages
datasetPresenter.description:
Toxoplasma gondii is a zoonotic pathogen for which felids serve as definitive hosts. In cats, the parasite undergoes several rounds of asexual replication before entering the sexual cycle which gives rise to oocysts that are shed into the environment. These then sporulate and become infective to humans and live stock. To understand the genes involved in the parasite development in the felid host and identify potential intervention targets, we designed a transcriptomic approach to compare the cat intestinal stages with the well characterised tachyzoites that mediate acute infection and tissue cysts that are responsible for chronic infection. Cats were infected with T. gondii CZ clone H3 tissue cysts from mouse brain and the intestinal stages were sampled at day 3, 5 and 7 post infection. As an input sample, we also collected tissue cysts from mouse brain. In vitro cultivated tachyzoites were also harvested. Total RNA was extracted, enriched for mRNA and used for cDNA synthesis. RNA-Seq was then performed to describe the transcriptomic repertoire of each developmental stage. RNA-seq datasets from each time point post inoculation with bradyzoites in kittens were subjected to cluster analysis and assigned to five enteroepithelial developmental stages (EES) according to their profile.

Cat enteroepithelial stages:
  • EES1 = very early enteroepithelial stages
  • EES2 = early enteroepithelial stages
  • EES3 = mixed enteroepithelial stages
  • EES4 = late enteroepithelial stages
  • EES5 = very late enteroepithelial stages

T. gondii tachyzoites were propagated on Vero cells before being used to infect human foreskin fibroblasts (HFFs). Confluent monolayers of HFFs were infected with approximately 10E^7 tachyzoites.

Protein preparations from infected cultures (human and parasite mixed) were trypsin digested, mixed with peptide internal standards and analysed by LC-MS/MS. Resulting spectra were searched (PEAKS Studio 7.0) against a combination of T. gondii protein sequence database (ToxoDB's "ToxoDB-8.0_TgondiiME49_AnnotatedProteins") and Human protein reference sequence database (UniProt, May 2013).

Samples:
16 hour infection of H.sapiens cells (GT1)
16 hour infection of H.sapiens cells (ME49)
16 hour infection of H.sapiens cells (VEG)
36 hour infection of H.sapiens cells (RH)

44 hour infection of H.sapiens cells (VEG)

datasetPresenter.name: tgonGT1_crisprPhenotype_CrisprScreen_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Fitness during the T. gondii lytic cycle. (Genome-Wide CRISPR Screen)
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome-wide loss of function screen (CRISPR) that measures each gene's contribution to Toxoplasma gondii fitness during infection of human fibroblasts. Phenotype score = log2 (sgRNA of infected cultures / sgRNA composition of original library)
datasetPresenter.description:
Genome-wide loss of function genetic screen in Toxoplasma gondii using CRISPR techonology.

Pooled CRISPR Screens
Toxoplasma gondii RH parasites constitutively expressing Cas9 and transfected with a library of single guide RNAs (sgRNAs) were used to infect confluent human foreskin fibroblast (HFF) cultures. The library contained ten sgRNAs against each of the 8,158 predicted protein-coding genes. Genomic DNA was extracted from the original library or from infected HFF cultures after 3 lytic cycles. Loci for sgRNA were amplified and subsequently sequenced on an Illumina HiSeq 2500.

Fitness or Phenotype Score:
The frequency of a given sgRNA corresponds to the relative abundance of parasites carrying the targeted disruption. The relative abundance of each integrated sgRNA (next-gen sequencing above) was compared to the composition of the original library. The phenotype score was calculated from 4 biological replicates as the log2 fold-change in abundance for sgRNAs targeting a given gene. To minimize type I error, only the top 5 scoring guides for each gene were averaged. Genes that contribute to parasite fitness will be represented by negative scores since loss of function of the gene reduces fitness and therefore fewer parasites survive three lytic cycles. The phenotype scores in this data set range from -6.89 to +2.96

The figure below from the publication shows some key genes repreented on the fitness graph
